feed.title: Project PANOPTES
feed.subtitle: PANOPTES is a citizen science project which aims to build low cost, robotic telescopes which can be used to detect transiting exoplanets.

entry.title: “Eh, What’s Up Doc?” - We’re Hiring!
entry.content:
We are seeking a postdoctoral researcher to assist in the development of the project’s cloud-based data reduction pipeline and to assist in the scientific use of PANOPTES data for exoplanet identification and characterization. Check out the AAS job posting for more information.

AAS Job Register
entry.summary: We are seeking a postdoctoral researcher to assist in the development of the project’s cloud-based data reduction pipeline and to assist in the scientific use of PANOPTES data for exoplanet identification and characterization. Check out the AAS job posting for more information.

entry.title: PANOPTES @ AA233
entry.content: The American Astronomical Society’s 233rd Meeting is coming up and Project PANOPTES is getting ready! One of our undergraduate interns will be presenting a poster of the unit she built (PAN012) in just 10 weeks at Caltech. We’ll also be giving a science talk complete with shiny new light curves using data obtained from PAN012 during the internship. Look for us there!
entry.summary: The American Astronomical Society’s 233rd Meeting is coming up and Project PANOPTES is getting ready! One of our undergraduate interns will be presenting a poster of the unit she built (PAN012) in just 10 weeks at Caltech. We’ll also be giving a science talk complete with shiny new light curves using data obtained from PAN012 during the internship. Look for us there!

entry.title: PANOPTES on StarDate!
entry.content:
PANOPTES was honored to be featured on the radio station StarDate put out by the McDonald Observatory and aired on many NPR stations throughout the USA.

Listen to the segment online and tune in to StarDate whenever you can for a brief update about what is happening in the sky each night.
entry.summary: PANOPTES was honored to be featured on the radio station StarDate put out by the McDonald Observatory and aired on many NPR stations throughout the USA.

entry.title: HawaiiCon 2018
entry.content:
Science fiction or science fact? Panny and some of the PANOPTES team make a trip to HawaiiCon 2018 to talk exoplanets and astronomy.

Say, who is that looking out from behind the screen?
entry.summary: Science fiction or science fact? Panny and some of the PANOPTES team make a trip to HawaiiCon 2018 to talk exoplanets and astronomy.

entry.title: PAN012 Party!
entry.content:
What better way to celebrate the successful build of PAN012 than with a party on the roof at Caltech?

Not only did PAN012 get built in 10 weeks by two students, but they were also able to obtain to recover a full transit of HD189733 right from this very same rooftop! Definitely a good way to end the summer!

Congratulations to Aru and Montu for a job well done!

Check out the photo album for more pictures and video of the launch party.

Photo Album
entry.summary: What better way to celebrate the successful build of PAN012 than with a party on the roof at Caltech?

entry.title: New Forum Launched!
entry.content:
We’ve started a new forum to talk about all things PANOPTES. Got a question? Building a unit? Have a great idea? Sign up and ask away!

Forum
entry.summary: We’ve started a new forum to talk about all things PANOPTES. Got a question? Building a unit? Have a great idea? Sign up and ask away!

entry.title: SCaLE Conference 16x
entry.content:
PANOPTES team member Wilfred Gee gave a talk at this year’s Southern California Linux Expo (SCaLE 16x) in Pasadena, CA on March 08 of this year.

Read more at the Conference Abstract.
entry.summary: PANOPTES team member Wilfred Gee gave a talk at this year’s Southern California Linux Expo (SCaLE 16x) in Pasadena, CA on March 08 of this year.
